answers.answer: I had a nuclear stress test done 4 years ago after complaints of shortness of breath with exertion and chest pains.  The day of the test, they injected Thalium (not Valium) and hooked me up with leads to monitor heart activity.  Then I got on a treadmill and they calculated what my max heart rate could safely be.  They started up the treadmill and I watched my heart activity being recorded on the the TV screen, as the treadmill speed up.  The Dr.was talking to me when I felt the first PVC start, I told him that I felt one and he looked on the screen and saw it, then there were several more.  He got my heartrate up to around 180 and said we could go to 190 if I wanted to, I told him I didnt really want to.  After the treadmill, I had to go and sit down in a machine that took nuclear scans of the heart's reaction to the stress test.  A small portion of the machine moves in a panoramic motion around your chest while you sit still.  It seemed to take around 40 minutes.  None of it was painful.  He said he would call me the next day or so after reviewing the results.  He called me that night at home and said that the tests showed a low ejection fraction of my left ventricle and suggested a blocked artery, I was 28 years old.  He set up a cardiac cath that week.  It, thankfully came out to be a false positive as the heart cath. showed good arteries.I have since in the past couple of years experienced the same exact symptoms as you mentioned!  I even explained the feeling in my left arm as feeling like a blood pressure cuff was squeezing it, I apologized to the Dr. becuase I didnt know any other way to describe it.  My fingers will begin to tingle and not really be numb, but will have like a decreased sensation.  My calves have started cramping in the last few months, at one time my right calf was swollen a half inch larger than my left.If you feel like you have questions you didnt think of at the apt., Im sure you can call the office and ask the nurse there.  They usually understand that you think of all your questions once you get home and re-run the apt through your mind a few times!  And best of luck--post and let us know how it turns out!Mel
